Another interesting figure was William "Bloody Bill" Anderson, a Confederate guerrilla leader who operated in Missouri and Kansas during the Civil War. Anderson and his men were responsible for a number of brutal attacks on Union soldiers and civilians, and he was known for his ruthless tactics. Anderson was killed in 1864, but his legacy as a violent and controversial figure lives on.

In terms of the Copperhead movement, there were several prominent figures involved in Illinois. One was Clement Vallandigham, a Democratic politician and lawyer who was a vocal opponent of the war and the Lincoln administration. Vallandigham was arrested and tried for treason in 1863 after he gave a speech in which he called for an end to the war. He was eventually exiled to the Confederacy, but returned to Ohio after the war.

Another notable figure was Alexander Long, a Copperhead who was active in southern Illinois. Long was known for his inflammatory speeches and was arrested several times for his pro-Confederate activities. He was eventually imprisoned at Camp Douglas in Chicago, where he died in 1865.
